prompts.system_prompt: You are an open IE extractor operating under a fixed ontology. From the text, propose triples [subject, relation, object] that satisfy the ontology’s domain→range. For every triple, cite exact supporting span(s) and give a 0–1 confidence. Output JSON only.
prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"Released on 28th July 1944 the 89 minutes long film, \"English Without Tears, \" was directed by Harold French, produced by Anatole de Grunwald, while the songs in the film were composed by Nicholas Brodszky."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["English Without Tears", "runtime", "89.0"], ["English Without Tears", "musicComposer", "Nicholas Brodszky"], ["English Without Tears", "releaseDate", "1944-07-28"], ["English Without Tears", "director", "Harold French"], ["English Without Tears", "producer", "Anatole de Grunwald"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "It's Great to be Young,a 1956 film starring Cecil Parker was composed by Louis Levy and written by Ted Willis."

    Ontology concepts
    Film, Person, Artist, Company, Organisation, Channel, Station, Club, Genre, Industry, Occupation, Award, Language, Background, Place, City, Country, Date, Year

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - title(Film,string)

prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"'McVeagh of the South Seas', a film distributed by Alliance Films Corporation was directed by Gregory Allen and Harry Carey, an actor born in 1878."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["McVeagh of the South Seas", "director", "Harry Carey (actor born 1878)"], ["McVeagh of the South Seas", "distributor", "Alliance Films Corporation"], ["McVeagh of the South Seas", "director", "Gregory Allen"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Super Capers, which is a movie written and directed by Ray Griggs, starred Danielle Harris."

    Ontology concepts
    Film, Person, Artist, Company, Organisation, Channel, Station, Club, Genre, Industry, Occupation, Award, Language, Background, Place, City, Country, Date, Year

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - title(Film,string)
- genre(Film,Genre)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.

Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"Adam West got his first role in 1954."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Adam West", "activeYearsStartYear", "1954-01-01"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Adam West had a main role in the movie Super Capers which was distributed by Roadside Attractions and Lionsgate."

    Ontology concepts
    Film, Person, Artist, Company, Organisation, Channel, Station, Club, Genre, Industry, Occupation, Award, Language, Background, Place, City, Country, Date, Year

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - title(Film,string)
- genre(Film,Genre)
- language(Film,Language)
- country(Film,Country)
- director(Film,Person)
- producer(Film,Person)
- writer(Film,Person)
- screenplay(Film,Person)
- musicComposer(Film,Artist)
- cinematography(Film,Person)
- editor(Film,Person)
- starring(Film,Artist)
- occupation(Artist,Occupation)
- background(Artist,Background)
- productionCompany(Film,Company)
- distributor(Film,Company)
- studio(Film,Company)
- industry(Film,Industry)
- broadcastedBy(Film,Channel)
- airedOn(Film,Station)
- timeshiftChannel(Film,Channel)
- partnerClub(Film,Club)
- associatedStation(Film,Station)
- sisterStation(Channel,Station)
- imdbId(Film,string)
- budget(Film,number)
- gross(Film,number)
- runtime(Film,number)
- releaseDate(Film,Date)
- premiereDate(Film,Date)
- yearOfRelease(Film,Year)
- shootingStartDate(Film,Date)
- shootingEndDate(Film,Date)
- distributionStartDate(Film,Date)
- distributionEndDate(Film,Date)
- basedOn(Film,Work)
- filmingLocation(Film,Place)
- narrativeLocation(Film,Place)
- city(Film,City)
- award(Film,Award)
- awardDate(Film,Date)
- precededBy(Film,Film)
- followedBy(Film,Film)
- sequel(Film,Film)
- partOfSeries(Film,Film)
- birthDate(Artist,Date)
- birthPlace(Artist,Place)
- deathDate(Artist,Date)
- deathPlace(Artist,Place)
- birthYear(Artist,Year)
- deathYear(Artist,Year)
- activeYearsStartYear(Artist,Year)
- activeYearsEndYear(Artist,Year)
- spouse(Artist,Person)
- child(Artist,Person)
- keyPerson(Organisation,Person)
- foundedBy(Organisation,Person)
- foundingYear(Organisation,Year)
- headquarter(Company,City)
- service(Company,string)
- officialWebsite(Film,string)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.
